text: Hi.
This is Shawn Levy.

I’m the director and one of
the producers of The Adam
Project.
“What’s with the lightsaber?”
“It’s not a lightsaber.
Jesus Christ, Adam.
I need you to play it cool.”

So this scene here
is pretty much

the one where the premise
of the entire picture
gets set up.

Walker Scobell, who
plays young Adam,

is questioning
this man who has

appeared in his back shed,
played by Ryan Reynolds.

And it’s the scene where the
12-year-old realizes that he
is talking to his future self.

“You go to Franklin
Middle School,

where you’ve been
suspended two,

maybe three times
for fighting,

which is ironic because
you can’t fight to save
your life.”
“Hawking, zip it!”

And, obviously,
minds are blown.

“How do you know
my dog’s name?”
“Because I named him.”

So a lot of sci-fi
movies, they

lay out exposition
in a cerebral way.

I love that this movie
was declaring its premise

in a relatable
and domestic way.

And so it was important that
they have the same words

but that the same words are
in perfect synchronicity.

So I remember Ryan and
I saying to Walker,

listen, imagine a mirror right
here between Ryan and you.
When Ryan turns, you turn.

When you feel Ryan
take a breath to talk,
you take a breath to talk.

And we were very blunt with
Walker about the need for him

to mirror Ryan’s timing and
that Ryan would quarterback

it, and Walker would
follow his lead.

“You knew how to
time my breathing.
We have the same scar.

And you’re wearing
my dad’s watch.”

So much of this movie
is about rhythm,

and where we
quicken things up,
and where we slow things down.

And that watch beat, I wanted
the poignance and the weight
of that to land.

And, of course, one way
to make moments land

is to vary the rhythm with
which things are said or done
on screen.
